metadata.case_name: Timber Merchant (Appellant) v. Commissioner of Income-tax (Respondent)

facts.text: On 5th February 1930, appellant obtained a loan of Rs. 1 lakh from the Bank of India on the joint security of himself and one Mamraj Rambhagat.
On the same day, Mamraj Rambhagat obtained a loan of Rs. 1 lakh from the Imperial Bank of India, Bombay on the joint security of himself and the appellant.
Appellant paid off his loan of Rs. 1 lakh to the Bank of India.
Mamraj Rambhagat failed to repay his loan; Imperial Bank realized Rs. 1,00,626 (principal + interest Rs. 626) from the appellant on 24th March 1930.
Mamraj Rambhagat failed in his business and his estate went into the hands of receivers on 25th April 1930.
Appellant opened a ledger account in the name of Mamraj Rambhagat and debited Rs. 1,00,626 to this account.
Appellant received dividends from receivers: Rs. 31,446 on 30th October 1930, Rs. 9,434 on 25th April 1934, Rs. 4,716 on 17th May 1938, aggregating Rs. 45,596.
Balance of Rs. 55,030 unpaid, written off as bad debt in assessment year 1941-42 (account year 1997 Ramnavmi).
Claimed as allowable deduction under section 10 of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922.
Income-tax Officer disallowed claim holding it was capital loss; Appellate Assistant Commissioner affirmed.

Before Appellate Assistant Commissioner, appellant argued custom in Bombay to secure loans on joint security for lower interest; submitted old pro-notes; cited Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras v. S. A. S. Ramaswamy Chettiar.
Appellate Assistant Commissioner distinguished Ramaswamy Chettiar on facts, held loss capital.
Income Tax Appellate Tribunal held custom accepted by Department, no distinction between money-lending and timber business, followed Ramaswamy Chettiar, allowed claim.
Tribunal referred question to High Court under section 66(1): Whether Rs. 55,030 allowable as bad debt under section 10(2)(xi).

Calcutta High Court answered negative on 8th June 1951, holding no part of loan applied to appellant's business, debt not trading debt of timber business; distinguished Ramaswamy Chettiar citing S. R. Subramanya Pillai.
Appeal to Supreme Court with certificate under section 66A(2).

legal_issues.text: Whether the loss of Rs. 55,030 suffered by the appellant was a capital loss or a trading loss or a bad debt incurred by the appellant in the course of carrying on his business of timber, allowable under section 10(2)(xi) of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922.

petitioner_arguments.text: It was usual custom in Bombay to secure loans on joint security from Banks; preferred by Banks and traders for lower interest; appellant borrowed frequently on joint security.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Custom; Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras v. S. A. S. Ramaswamy Chettiar

petitioner_arguments.text: Mutual suretyship: A joins B as surety in consideration for B joining A; thus essential to financing appellant's timber business; loss is trading loss/bad debt of timber business.

respondent_arguments.text: No part of loan from Imperial Bank applied to appellant's business; debt not trading/business debt of timber business; appellant not in business of standing surety.
Custom not mutual or essential; loss capital.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras v. S. R. Subramanya Pillai

court_reasoning.text: No part of monies borrowed on joint security went to finance appellant's timber business; all utilised by Mamraj in his business; debt not due to appellant's timber business.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Monies not required for appellant's business.

court_reasoning.text: Custom not proved as mutual accommodation essential; appellant could procure surety without reciprocating; old pro-notes insufficient; not incident of timber business.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Custom limited to joint security for lower interest, not requiring mutuality.

court_reasoning.text: Ramaswamy Chettiar distinguished: peculiar to Nattukottai Chettiars' money-lending with mutuality; absent here.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Elements of mutuality and essentiality to business wanting.

court_reasoning.text: Subramanya Pillai analogous: loss on joint borrowing for another's benefit is capital, not business loss.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Debt must be trading debt of the assessee's trade.

holdings.text: Loss of Rs. 55,030 is capital loss, not trading loss or bad debt of appellant's timber business; not allowable under section 10(2)(xi).

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras v. S. A. S. Ramaswamy Chettiar
precedents_cited.relevance: Custom among Nattukottai Chettiars for mutual suretyship in money-lending; confined to peculiar facts, not applicable to timber business.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras v. S. R. Subramanya Pillai
precedents_cited.relevance: Loss on joint borrowing where part for another's business is capital loss, not deductible; analogous to present case.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Reference and appeal provisions; bad debt deduction only for trading debt of assessee's business.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court upheld High Court's negative answer to the reference question, holding the loss as capital and not allowable as bad debt under section 10(2)(xi).

key_quotes.text: The debt must therefore be one which can properly be called a trading debt and a debt of the trade, the profits of which are being computed.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Test for allowability of bad debt under section 10(2)(xi).

key_quotes.text: It is their custom to borrow from banks for the purpose of lending out the sums so obtained at higher rates of interest. The banks require such overdrafts to be guaranteed by other Chettiars.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains mutuality in Ramaswamy Chettiar case, absent here.
